Grouped_Utterances: Success for me means getting my writing out there, maybe getting published, or landing a role that I really connect with. Just feeling like I'm making progress.

I've been okay, a bit up and down, but overall not too bad. It's been a mixed bag, honestly. Some days I'm really productive, and other days I just feel stuck. I think it’s partly fear of failure. I put a lot of pressure on myself to succeed, and when I don't, it really gets to me. Well, I’ve been trying to write every day, but some days I just can’t find the motivation.  I think it’s a mix of self-doubt and distractions. Sometimes I just scroll mindlessly on my phone instead of writing. I’ve tried setting timers for writing sessions, but I struggle to stick to it when I’m not feeling inspired. When I feel inspired, I can write for hours. It’s like everything just flows out of me. I think being around other creative people helps, or sometimes just getting out of the house and experiencing new things. Not really. I’ve been a bit reclusive lately, just stuck in my routine. There’s a local writer’s group that meets weekly. I’ve been meaning to join but haven’t yet.
I guess I’m just nervous about meeting new people and sharing my work. I often think that I’m not good enough or that my work isn’t worth sharing.
I finished a short story I’d been working on for weeks.  It felt really good, like I accomplished something.

It might be helpful to practice reframing those thoughts. For example, instead of "I'm not good enough," you could say, "I am learning and growing as a writer." How does that sound? That sounds like a good idea. I can try that. Awesome! Let’s work on that together. If you catch yourself thinking negatively, try to write down the thought and then reframe it. I can do that. I’ll keep a journal for it. Perfect! Journaling can also help you track your progress and reflect on your feelings. How do you feel about that? I think it’s a good idea. It’ll give me a chance to see how I’m improving over time.

Maybe if I just go to observe first without sharing anything. Just to get a feel for it. That’s a smart approach. Observing can help ease the pressure. Would you like to set a goal to attend the next meeting? Yes, I think I can do that!
